In this study, a series of Co–Ni–Al–layered double hydroxides (CoxNiyAl1–LDHs) was successfully prepared via a simple co-precipitation method with Na2CO3 and NaOH as the precipitants. After the calcination of the CoxNiyAl1–LDH precursors, the Co–Ni–Al–O mixed oxides were formed and used as highly efficient catalysts in the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. The Ni addition to CoAlOx can induce the formation of interactions between Co–Ni species and affect the dispersion of metal active centers, thereby greatly influencing the catalytic performance. The typical Co2Ni1Al1Ox sample with a Co:Ni molar ratio of 2:1 exhibited the highest surface area (165 m2/g) and the best catalytic performance (80.0% ethylbenzene conversion and 88.9% acetophenone selectivity). The high catalytic efficiency was mainly attributed to the high-efficiency synergistic effect between the highly dispersed active center Co and the promoter Ni species. More importantly, the good recyclability and stability of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst made it more competitive. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Layered double hydroxides Co–Ni–Al–O complex oxide Selective oxidation Ethylbenzene Acetophenone 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of alkanes and alkyl aromatics for preparing high-value-added alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, carboxylic acids, and other chemical intermediates is a very important chemical transformation in the organic production process, which has attracted much attention [1–5]. Accordingly, the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone is one of the hot topics in this field. The main driving force behind this is that acetophenone is an important chemical raw material widely used in synthesizing fragrances, dyes, plasticizers, pharmaceutical intermediates, and so on [6,7]. However, the traditional acetophenone synthesis process has disadvantages of low yield, high cost, serious pollution, large energy consumption, and difficulty in product separation, prohibiting it to meet the requirement of the current concept of an environmentally friendly synthesis [8,9]. Therefore, the development of green and efficient catalysts and the exploration of new acetophenone production processes have considerable economic benefits and theoretical research value. A series of clean oxidants, including tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) [10–14], hydrogen peroxide [15,16], and molecular oxygen (O2) [17,18], have been extensively studied by scholars to achieve the oxidation process of ethylbenzene side-chain CH bonds. Ethylbenzene oxidation is a typical aromatic side-chain oxidation. Many catalysts have been reported relevant to the heterogeneous catalytic reaction system for the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene, which mainly include a supported Mn catalyst [19,20], Co-based oxide [21,22], metal-supported molecular sieve materials [23–29], carbon material [30–36], and metal–organic framework materials [37–40]. However, few of these catalysts have both high activity and selectivity. For example, single Mn- and single Ni-supported catalysts exhibit high acetophenone selectivity, but low ethylbenzene conversion [41–44]. Single Cosupported catalysts have attracted much attention due to their better catalytic performances in the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone compared to other metal-supported catalysts [21,45]; however, the ethylbenzene conversion rate and the acetophenone selectivity remain low. Therefore, many researchers have focused on catalysts with bimetallic species supported on suitable carriers [20,46,47]. A great enhancement of the catalytic performance is expected based on the high-efficiency synergistic effect of bimetallic species and the strong metal–support interaction. The hydrotalcite material is a kind of anionic clay with a two-dimensional structure, which is also called a layered double hydroxide (LDH). Its formula can be expressed as [M(II)1−xM(III)x(OH)2]x+[X x/m m−•nH2O]x−, in which M(II) and M(III) are the divalent and trivalent metal cations on the laminate, respectively. LDHs can be topologically transformed into mixed metal oxides (MMO) with a high catalytic activity through thermal decomposition [48]. They have strong thermal stability and basic sites and a large specific surface area and can evenly distribute the loaded metal elements. Xie [1] used the Al2O3@CoCuAl-MMO catalyst obtained from the Cu–Co–hydrotalcite precursor to oxidize ethylbenzene to acetophenone, which consequently showed a good catalytic performance. At the same time, Co-based hydrotalcite materials have very efficient catalytic properties and are widely used in oxidation [49,50], hydrogenation [51,52], electrocatalysis [53], and other reactions. Considering the high-efficiency catalytic advantages of hydrotalcite materials, we use herein CoxNiyAl1–LDHs precursors to prepare a series of highly dispersed and tunable CoxNiyAl1Ox metal nanocatalysts with tunable chemical properties. The active center sites, synergistic effect of Ni addition on the Co-based catalyst, and their catalytic performances in the ethylbenzene to acetophenone oxidation are systematically investigated. To the best of our knowledge, only a few studies have investigated the use of catalysts obtained from the bimetallic LDH material precursor for ethylbenzene oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Ethylbenzene (99% purity) was obtained from Tianjin Komiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Analytical-grade Co(NO3)2•6H2O, Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, Al(NO3)3•9H2O, urea, NaOH, and Na2CO3 were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and used without further purification. TBHP and acetic acid glacial were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. γ − A l 2 O 3 was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation CoxNiyAl1–LDHs with a molar ratio of (Co2+ + Ni2+) / Al3+ = 3, Co2+ + Ni2+ = 30 mmol and x/y = 3:0, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:3, and 0:3 and corresponding single metal catalysts were synthesized by a coprecipitation method. A mixed aqueous solution of nickel, cobalt, and aluminum nitrates (0.15 M) and a Na2CO3 solution (0.1 M) were added dropwise into deionized water and maintained at room temperature under vigorous stirring for 10 min. Subsequently, a (0.15 M) NaOH solution was added to keep the pH at 10 ± 0.5. The resultant slurry was aged in the mother liquid at 80 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid precipitate was thoroughly washed with deionized water until the pH value of the filtrate was approximately 7. The filter cake was then dried at 80 °C in air for 24 h. The obtained samples are referred to herein as CoxNiyAl1–LDHs, where x and y refer to the feed Co:Ni molar ratio. The CoxNiyAl1–LDHs precursors underwent a calcination procedure at 500 °C for 4 h (from room temperature to 500 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1) in air to form the final MMO catalysts and designed as CoxNiyAl1Ox (the former x and y refer to the feed Co:Ni molar ratio, while the latter x is the fixed statement “x”). For a comparison, a C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 precursor prepared via the impregnation method (IMP) and Co2Ni1Al1–LDHs–Urea synthesized by the urea precipitation method were also prepared in this work. The feed Co:Ni molar ratios were both 2:1, referring to the typical sample of Co2Ni1Al1Ox earlier. The precursors were calcined in air to form the final catalysts and designed as C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 and Co2Ni1Al1Ox–Urea. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD pattern of the catalyst was measured by a D/MAX-2400 X-ray diffractometer through Cu-kɑ radiation (λ = 154.2 Å). The test voltage was 40 kV, while the test current was 50 mA. The scan range of the test sample was 2θ = 5°–60°, while the scan rate was 10° min−1. A Nicolet Nexus 670 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer was used to measure the infrared spectrum (FT-IR). First, the catalyst was ground with an appropriate amount of KBr (spectrum pure). Next, the tablet test was performed. The device resolution was 4 cm−1, and the scanning range was 380–4000 cm−1. A high-resolution FEI-Talos F200s series transmission electron microscope was used to observe the HAADF-STEM, EDS, and mapping spectra of the catalyst. TEM and HRTEM images were obtained on the JEM-2010 TEM. An inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110) was used to detect the actual metal loading in the catalyst. The sample (0.0445 g) was dissolved in 25 mL of aqua regia. We took 1 mL solution and diluted it for 100 times for testing after a complete digestion. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus was used to test the specific surface area and the pore size distribution through nitrogen physical adsorption and desorption experiments at −196 °C. Prior to the testing, the catalyst was degassed in a vacuum at 150 °C for 8 h. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurement and the metal dispersion were performed by employing an AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Approximately 100 mg of each sample was placed in quartz reactors and reduced in a stream of 20 mL min−1 H2 (10 vol% in Ar) at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The PHI5702 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer of the American Physical Electronics Company was used to analyze the valence state of the elements to be measured in the sample. The excitation light source was an Al target. The power was 250 W. The voltage was 14 KV. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement The liquid-phase selective oxidation of ethylbenzene was performed in a glass reactor equipped with a condenser and a magnetic stirrer. In our previous research results, acetic acid was tested as the most suitable reaction solvent probably because the ethylbenzene hydrogen peroxide intermediate formed in the reaction process is more prone to decomposition in an acidic environment, and acetic acid can effectively disperse the substrate [16]. Thus, acetic acid was chosen as the reaction solvent in this work. Ethylbenzene (5 ml), acetic acid (10 ml), and a catalyst (0.10 g, 0.15 g, 0.20 g, 0.25 g, and 0.30 g) were typically added into a 100 ml two-neck flask immersed in an oil bath, followed by 70% aqueous TBHP with the substrate/TBHP volume ratio of (1:1, 1:2, 1:3, 1:4, and 1:5). The reaction was performed at a certain temperature for a certain period with continuous magnetic stirring at 1000 rpm. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and the reaction mixture was dehydration by anhydrous sodium sulfate. To investigate the catalyst reusability, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixtures, washed with ethyl alcohol, and finally dried at 80 °C for 24 h. A fresh substrate and the recovered catalyst were employed in the repeated tests. The reaction product was analyzed using a GC-7890II gas chromatograph equipped with high-purity nitrogen as a carrier gas and an SE-30 capillary column (50 m * 0.53 mm * 1 μm) in the FID detector. The injector and detector temperatures were set at 250 °C. The column temperature was set at 160 °C. Bromobenzene was used as the internal standard. Ethylbenzene (EB), acetophenone (AP), benzaldehyde (BA), 1-phenylethanol (1-PA), benzoic acid, and others that were chromatographically pure were used for a qualitative determination according to the retention time. The product analysis was confirmed by the gas chromatography−mass spectrometry implemented through gas chromatography (GC, 7890A, Agilent) coupled with mass spectrometry (MS, 5975C, Agilent). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 A depicts the XRD patterns of the CoxNiyAl1–LDHs catalyst precursors. All samples presented a series of characteristic diffractions at 11.7°, 22.8°, 34.7°, 38.8°, 46.4°, 61.1°, and 61.9°, which corresponded to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) planes of the hydrotalcite structure phase (JCPDS 51-0045) [54], respectively. This confirmed that the hydrotalcite structure materials were successfully prepared. These hydrotalcite precursors were roasted at 500 °C, and all turned to bimetal CoxNiyAl1Ox and monometallic (Co3Al1Ox and Ni3Al1Ox) mixed oxides with different chemical components (Fig. 1B). The diffraction peaks of the Co3O4 (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) reflection were found for the Co3Al1Ox sample, while the diffraction peaks of the NiO (111), (200), (220), and (311) reflection were seen for the Ni3Al1Ox samples. The main diffraction peaks of the (400) and (440) reflection of the Co3O4 spinel phase slightly shifted to a lower angle with the introduction of Ni. This may be due to the gradual substitution of Co2+ by Ni2+ in the microstructure. In addition, the absence of an Al2O3 phase may be explained as a proper mixing of that phase within the CoxNiyAl1Ox framework [51]. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns for the three comparison samples prepared via different methods with a 2:1 Co:Ni molar ratio. Fig. 2A(a) depicts that the C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 precursor prepared by the impregnation method does not have a hydrotalcite structure. Meanwhile, Fig. 2A(b) illustrates that the Co2Ni1Al1–LDHs–Urea precursor prepared using urea as a precipitating agent possesses the mixed phases of a hydrotalcite structure and other impurity species. After the calcination of these precursors, the CoNi catalysts synthesized by different preparation methods showed the same metal oxide phases (Fig. 2B). The C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 crystallinity was the highest, whereas that of Co2Ni1Al1Ox was the lowest, from which the highest dispersion of the active metal oxide sites in the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst can be speculated. Figure S1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption curves and the corresponding pore size distribution curves of the samples. Figure S1(A) shows that all catalysts have IV adsorption–desorption isotherms, with the typical H2 hysteresis loops for the CoxNiyAl1Ox series samples obtained from the CoxNiyAl1–LDHs precursors, C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 and Co2Ni1Al1Ox–Urea, indicating the presence of some mesoporous mesopores in all the samples. Figure S1(B) presents that the CoxNiyAl1Ox series samples all possessed relatively intensive pore size distributions, and Co2Ni1Al1Ox was the most intensive one with the highest peak value at approximately 23 nm. However, the pore size distributions for the C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 and Co2Ni1Al1Ox–Urea samples were broad. Table 1 summarizes the surface areas, pore volumes, and average pore diameters of the samples. The Co2Ni1Al1Ox sample possessed the highest specific surface area of 165.2 m2/g. The specific surface areas for the CoxNiyAl1Ox series samples were all much higher than those for the C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 (58.0 m2/g) and Co2Ni1Al1Ox–Urea (88.2 m2/g) samples, indicating the advantages of the synthesis method in this study. We performed an XPS characterization of the Co2.25Ni0.75Al1Ox, Co2Ni1Al1Ox, and Co1.5Ni1.5Al1Ox bimetallic nanocatalysts to further study the interaction between the CoNi species. Fig. 3 shows the results. Two sets of asymmetric peaks were found at 775–790 eV and 790–810 eV, which belonged to the electron energy levels of the Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 orbitals [55,56], respectively. The peaks of the Co 2p 3/2 energy level was split. Co3+ with no satellite peak in the range of 780.4–779.9 eV belonged to the octahedral structure, while Co2+ was in the range of 781.4–782.0 eV and exhibited a satellite peak in the range of 785–790 eV, indicating belongingness to the regular tetrahedral structure [57,58]. The Co3+ content gradually decreased as the Ni content increased possibly because the Ni introduction led to the formation of more CoAl spinel phases. In Fig. 3D, the peak near 855.6 eV of the Ni 2p 3/2 energy level was attributed to Ni2+, which is consistent with the XRD result. In addition, Fig. 5A–C show that the characteristic peak of Co 2p 3/2 slightly shifted to the direction of a low binding energy with the increase of the Ni content. This indicates that the Co species obtained some electrons, making the surrounding electron cloud density increase [49]. Table 2 presents the surface chemistry of CoxNiyAl1Ox with different chemical components. The surface ratios of Co3+/Co2+ for the series of CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts were almost the same, indicating that Cox+ on the surface of the bimetallic nanocatalyst synthesized in this work has a similar proportion of valence distribution. In terms of the reaction performance, the valence state of the surface Co had little effect on the oxidation performance of ethylbenzene, which was mainly affected by the change of the valence state of the Co metal in the bulk phase of the catalyst sheet. Table 2 also summarizes the surface and the bulk Co:Ni molar ratios for the CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts. The bulk Co:Ni molar ratio for the CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts was mainly consistent with their respective theoretical molar ratio, while the surface Co:Ni molar ratio was only about half of their corresponding bulk Co:Ni molar ratio for all the CoxNiyAl1Ox samples, implying that the Co species is not as easy to diffuse to the surface as the Ni species, and that the Co species is in excess in the bulk phase due to the Ni species addition. The decrease of the Co content and the increase of the Ni content in the surface phase might to be the keys to the effect on the oxidation performance of ethylbenzene. Furthermore, Ni may also play a role in dispersing the Co metal. Fig. 4 illustrates the TEM images of the CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts. The CoxNiyAl1Ox samples all inherited the structural characteristics of the layered bimetallic hydrotalcite and were composed of many closely packed nanosheets. Among Co2.25Ni0.75Al1Ox (Fig. 4A), Co2Ni1Al1Ox (Fig. 4B), and Co1.5Ni1.5Al1Ox (Fig. 4C), the Co2Ni1Al1Ox sample exhibited the highest particle dispersions, while the other two possessed some particle agglomerates. The HRTEM image of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox bimetallic nanocatalyst (Fig. 4D) shows that the lattice fringes of 0.285 nm and 0.143 nm appeared in two adjacent metal nanoparticles, which are attributed to the (220) crystal surface of the Co3O4 spinel phase and the (110) crystal surface of the NiO rock salt structure, respectively. The close contact of the Co and Ni species of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox bimetallic nanocatalyst was conducive to the enhancement of the interaction between the two metal species for generating new catalytically active species. Fig. 4E (HAADF-STEM and elemental maps) and F (EDX) show the surface scanning analysis of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox bimetallic nanocatalyst. The uniform distribution of the Co, Ni, Al, and O elements was observed in the entire catalyst, indicating the close contact and the strong interaction between different elements. Fig. 5 shows the FT-IR characterization results for the CoxNiyAl1Ox samples. Two infrared absorption bands appeared in the range of 400–1000 cm−1 in the Co2.25Ni0.75Al1Ox sample with a higher Co content. The infrared absorption band at about 669 cm−1 belonged to the tetrahedron Co2+, while the other absorption band at 566 cm−1 belonged to the octahedral Co3+ [59]. In the CoxNiyAl1Ox sample, the infrared absorption band of the Co2+ species gradually widened and shifted to a low wave number with the increase of the Ni content (Fig. 5a and b). The infrared absorption bands of the Co2+ and Co3+ species were almost invisible for the Co1.5Ni1.5Al1Ox samples (Fig. 5c), which may be caused by the increase of the NiO content and the decrease in the CoOx species crystallinity [60,61]. Fig. 6 displays the H2-TPR results for the CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts. The Co2.25Ni0.75Al1Ox catalyst (Fig. 6a) had a small hydrogen consumption peak at 146 °C, which was an adsorption site with a weaker H2 binding energy on the catalyst surface. This consumption peak gradually disappeared as the Co content decreased probably due to the decrease of the CoOx species and the weakening adsorption capacity of H2 on the catalyst surface. The hydrogen consumption peak in the lower temperature range (250–350 °C) can be attributed to the process of the first reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, while the broad H2 consumption peak in the temperature range of 400–800 °C belonged to the H2 consumption peak of different species. The later peak position moved to the high temperature with the increase of the Co content likely because of the increase of the Co2AlO4 and Co3O4 species resulting in the increased reduction temperature. A further study of the temperature range of 400–800 °C showed that it can be divided into two parts: first, the range of 400–600 °C is attributed to the reduction peak of the Co3O4 spinel phase, and the intensity of the reduction peak gradually increases with the Co content increase [62]; and second, the range of 600–800 °C is attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 [63] and the NiO, NiAl2O4, and (Ni,Co)2AlO4 species, which have a strong interaction with Al2O3 [57]. 3.2 Catalytic performances The catalytic performances for the CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts were evaluated through the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. Table 3 summarizes the ethylbenzene conversion and the selectivity of the main products over different catalysts. Both the catalytic performances of the monometallic Co3Al1Ox and Ni3Al1Ox were poor; however, the ethylbenzene conversion over the Co3Al1Ox catalyst was much higher than that for the Ni3Al1Ox catalyst, indicating the higher activity of Co to Ni. If the two metals are coprecipitated to prepare a CoxNiyAl1Ox bimetallic nanocatalyst, the conversion rate will greatly improve. Co2Ni1Al1Ox exhibited the best catalytic performance with an ethylbenzene conversion up to 80.0% and an acetophenone selectivity up to 88.9%. These results indicate that the bimetallic synergistic catalytic effect can significantly promote catalytic activities. In addition, the two comparison catalysts, namely C o 2 N i 1 / γ − A l 2 O 3 and Co2Ni1Al1Ox–Urea, which were prepared through the impregnation and urea precipitation methods, respectively, with the same metal loading as the Co2Ni1Al1Ox sample, both exhibited a much lower yield of acetophenone compared to Co2Ni1Al1Ox. This result indicates that the bimetallic mixed oxide catalysts obtained from the hydrotalcite structure precursors have much advantage for the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. Fig. 7 (A) shows the effect of the reaction time on the ethylbenzene oxidation at 120 °C. The ethylbenzene conversion rate and the acetophenone selectivity both increased with time, and the increase speed changed from fast to slow. The selectivity was up to 88.9% at 8 h possibly because more CC cleavage occurred to generate benzaldehyde, and the latter activity was weaker (i.e., mainly CH cleavage) as regards forming acetophenone [62]. After a 12 h reaction, the conversion rate reached a relatively high level and gradually approached equilibrium. Continued to extend the reaction time, the conversion rate hardly increased. During this period, a small amount of acetophenone may be overoxidized and converted to benzaldehyde, resulting in the decrease of the acetophenone selectivity. Fig. 7(B) depicts the effect of different catalyst dosages on the catalytic performance of ethylbenzene oxidation. When the catalyst amount exceeded 200 mg, the ethylbenzene conversion was basically unchanged, but the AP selectivity was found to be the best. Therefore, 200 mg of catalyst was chosen as the optimal amount. The ethylbenzene conversion seemed unchanged when the catalyst amount exceeded 200 mg probably due to the diffusion control factor. On the contrary, the AP selectivity decreased when the catalyst amount exceeded 200 mg probably due to the side reaction of benzaldehyde increasing through the demethanol of the ethylbenzene hydrogen peroxide intermediate with the excessive increase of the catalyst amount. Fig. 7(C) shows the effect of different amounts of TBHP on the catalytic performance of ethylbenzene oxidation. The conversion rate of ethylbenzene increased with the increase of the TBHP dose used when the volume ratio of TBHP to EB was less than 3, but remained unchanged when the TBHP dose was further increased. The acetophenone selectivity also showed a similar trend. Thus, the best ratio of oxidant dosage (TBHP) to reactant (EB) was 3. The reaction trend was not difficult to understand because the higher the oxidant used, the higher the number of active intermediates formed between the oxidant and the catalyst; and the higher the reactant conversion obtained. However, the active sites on the catalyst were finite; hence, it was unavailing when the amount of oxidant continued to increase and exceeded the critical value. Until now, most of the literatures consider the process of ethylbenzene oxidation as a free-radical reaction [64–66]. First, the electron-deficient metal ion in the catalyst induces the adsorption of the lone pair of electrons with the remote oxygen atom in the TBHP to activate the OO bond in the TBHP molecule to generate hydroxyl radicals (•OH) and tert-butyloxy radicals (t-Buo•) [67,68]. Second, the generated •OH and t-Buo• deprived the α-H of ethylbenzene to generate α-ethylbenzene radicals, which can capture the hydroxyl groups from the TBHP molecule to generate 1-PA and a new t-Buo•. The radical continued to deprive the α-H on 1-PA to form a dihydroxy rearrangement on the α-C to form the ethylbenzene hydrogen peroxide intermediate or directly generate the ethylbenzene hydrogen peroxide intermediate by immediately capturing the hydroxyl hydrogen on the 1-PA [69,70]. Finally, ethylbenzene hydrogen peroxide was further decomposed into benzaldehyde and acetophenone by dehydration or methanol removal. From the above analysis for Fig. 7(B) and (C), the results were basically consistent with the reaction mechanism speculated in the reported literatures. Fig. 7(D) depicts the effect of different reaction temperatures on catalytic ethylbenzene oxidation. The conversion rate (from 70.4% to 81.0%) and the selectivity (from 81.0% to 88.9%) both increased when the temperature rose from 100 °C to 120 °C due to the reaction rate's constant increase with the reaction temperature. However, when the temperature was further increased to 130 °C and higher, the conversion rate decreased. This was probably caused by the rapid decomposition of the TBHP at a higher temperature. The acetophenone selectivity also decreased likely because of the increase in the amount of benzaldehyde (BZ) from the breaking of the CC bond at the high temperature. Fig. 8 shows a comparison of the catalytic performances over different CoxNiyAl1Ox catalysts. The ethylbenzene conversion rate over these catalysts first increased and then decreased as the Co/Ni molar ratio increased. When Co:Ni = 2:1, the catalyst (Co2Ni1Al1Ox) exhibited the highest ethylbenzene conversion rate (80.0%) and acetophenone selectivity (88.9%). In contrast, the conversion rate and selectivity both decreased when the Co/Ni molar ratio was greater and lower than 2. The TOF values of the three catalysts based on the Co metal as the active center were calculated and found to be 54.2, 70.6, and 71.8 h−1 for Co2.25Ni0.75Al1Ox, Co2Ni1Al1Ox and Co1.5Ni1.5Al1Ox, respectively. The abovementioned TEM and BET characterization results showed that the increase of the Co or Ni content will cause the metal part to agglomerate and the specific surface area of the catalyst to decrease, leading to a deterioration of the catalytic performance. In addition, the catalytic performance of Co3Al1Ox was slightly better than that of Ni3Al1Ox. Therefore, the Ni addition in Co3Al1Ox can induce the formation of the interactions between the Co and Ni species and affect the dispersion of the metal active centers, greatly influencing the catalytic performance. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic performances of the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone over the reported catalysts in the previous literatures. It can be seen that the EB conversion and the AP selectivity over the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst prepared in this work were at the top level among the reported catalysts. Although the Al2O3@CoCuAl-MMO catalyst [1] and Pd(II) nanoparticle catalyst [74] exhibited the catalytic performances as good as our Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst in this work for the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone, the Al2O3@CoCuAl-MMO used the specially synthesized amorphous Al2O3 microspheres, which preparation was tedious and the catalyst composition was complicated, while the Pd catalysts are expensive. In addition, the reaction time was shorter over our Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst as compared those in comparison here. Thus, the hydrotalcite-based CoxNiyAl1Ox mixed oxide catalyst prepared through a simple coprecipitation method is more competitive. The cycle stability for the catalyst is a very important factor for the heterogeneous catalysts used in the liquid-phase reaction. Thus, the cycle reaction experiments on the typical Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst under the same reaction conditions were performed. We added approximately 0.100–0.032 g of fresh catalyst to ensure the same amount of catalyst (0.2 g) considering the inevitable loss during each reaction cycle. As shown in Fig. 9 , after the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst were recycled for at least four times without a significant deactivation, the ethylbenzene conversion rate only slightly decreased from 80.0% to 76.3%, and the selectivity to acetophenone was slightly reduced from 88.9% to 81.4%, indicating the good stability of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst for the liquid-phase ethylbenzene oxidation. Figure S2 depicts the TEM characterization and the results for the performed comparison between the recycled and fresh catalysts. After four consecutive cycles, the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst showed a slight agglomeration and growth of some nanometal particles; however, its morphology still maintained a flaky hydrotalcite structure (Figure S2[B]). Figure S3 shows the Co 2p XPS spectrum after four cycles of reaction. The amount of Co2+ was significantly greater than that of Co3+. Compared with the fresh Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst (Fig. 3(B)), the amount of Co3+ and Co2+ changed much, proving that the change in the valence state of the Co species is an important factor affecting the oxidation performance of ethylbenzene. 4 Conclusion We successfully prepared herein a mesoporous hydrotalcite bimetallic nanocatalyst with Co2Ni1Al1–LDHs as the precursor using the coprecipitation method. Due to its special mesoporous and sheet-like nanostructure, the catalyst exhibited a high catalytic performance for the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. By introducing the appropriate amount of the weakly active center of Ni, the high-efficiency synergistic effects of this bimetal catalyst (e.g., changing the catalyst pore size, increasing the catalyst specific surface area, changing the dispersion of the active centers and the exposed sites) made the catalytic performance over the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst largely improve compared to the catalyst without an added Ni promoter. The ethylbenzene conversion reached 80.0%, and the acetophenone selectivity was up to 88.9% over the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst under optimized reaction conditions. In addition, the catalyst exhibited good stability and can be recycled for at least four times without a significant deactivation. Therefore, the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst obtained from the Co2Ni1Al1–LDHs precursor has good practical application prospects. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a series of Co–Ni–Al–layered double hydroxides (CoxNiyAl1–LDHs) was successfully prepared via a simple co-precipitation method with Na2CO3 and NaOH as the precipitants. After the calcination of the CoxNiyAl1–LDH precursors, the Co–Ni–Al–O mixed oxides were formed and used as highly efficient catalysts in the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. The Ni addition to CoAlOx can induce the formation of interactions between Co–Ni species and affect the dispersion of metal active centers, thereby greatly influencing the catalytic performance. The typical Co2Ni1Al1Ox sample with a Co:Ni molar ratio of 2:1 exhibited the highest surface area (165 m2/g) and the best catalytic performance (80.0% ethylbenzene conversion and 88.9% acetophenone selectivity). The high catalytic efficiency was mainly attributed to the high-efficiency synergistic effect between the highly dispersed active center Co and the promoter Ni species. More importantly, the good recyclability and stability of the Co2Ni1Al1Ox catalyst made it more competitive.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrotalcite-based CoxNiyAl1Ox mixed oxide as a highly efficient catalyst for selective ethylbenzene oxidation
